awd_titl_txt: JINA Center for the Evolution of the Elements
awd_abstract_narration:
Much remains unknown about the origin and evolution of the elements that comprise the universe beyond those created in the Big Bang. Making significant advances in these areas requires investigations at the intersection of nuclear physics and astrophysics. Through this Physics Frontiers Centers (PFC) award the Joint Institute for Nuclear Astrophysics - Center for the Evolution of the Elements (JINA-CEE) will focus on answering closely connected open questions related to the origin of the elements and the properties of dense matter probed by neutron stars. JINA-CEE will build on the expertise and technical developments from its past two PFC awards and use innovative laboratory experiments, combined with theoretical and computational approaches, to address the broad range of nuclear physics and astrophysics challenges underlying these science goals. The resulting insights will be integrated into comprehensive physics models of element creation and neutron stars that are then compared to existing and new observational data. JINA-CEE will continue to have educational and research impacts within the nuclear astrophysics community through its interdisciplinary workshop, school, and visitor programs. In addition it will create new multi-institutional graduate course modules and undergraduate course components while reaching out to K-12 students, teachers, and the general public.

The transition from a three element (hydrogen, helium, and lithium) universe, with a small number of isotopes, to a chemically diverse cosmos containing eighty-two long-lived elements with hundreds of isotopes, is significant and not well understood. Neutron star matter plays an important role for the origin of the elements, as it shapes the synthesis of many of the heavy elements in nature produced in core-collapse supernovae and in neutron star mergers. JINA-CEE will explore two closely interrelated questions through experimental, theoretical, and computational approaches: "How were the elements beyond hydrogen and helium created during the first billion years after the Big Bang?" and "What are the properties of neutron-rich nuclear matter and how can it be probed by observations of neutron stars?"

por.por_cntn:
The Joint Institute for Nuclear Astrophysics, Center for the Evolution of the Elements (JINA-CEE) addressed fundamental open questions about the origin the chemical elements and their continuous nuclear transformations in the Cosmos. These nuclear processes and the resulting elements are the foundation of the solar system and life on Earth. JINA-CEE brought together 757 scientists from 87 institutions and from a broad range of fields and disciplines spanning nuclear science, astronomy, astrophysics, computational physics, and geo-chemistry with a diverse set of expertise in theory, accelerator experiments, astronomical observations, chemical analysis of stardust, and computational modeling. It created a unique interdisciplinary, large-scale network that transformed the way research at the interface of nuclear physics and astrophysics is done and served as a model for numerous similar networks now established across the world. JINA-CEE served as a center for the field of nuclear astrophysics, with more than 400 scientists participating annually in various activities such as workshops, conferences and visitor programs. It fostered broad participation by creating an inclusive research environment with participants from various types of universities, national laboratories, and minority serving institutions.

The unique interdisciplinary research projects and the network wide rapid exchange of data and ideas across field boundaries led to 1514 scientific journal publications to date. Major findings included the discovery of novel element creating processes in stars; the identification and characterization of nuclear transformation deep inside neutrons stars that open a window into the properties of the densest matter in the universe; a precise determination of the nuclear reactions that create neutrinos in the sun, and the elements of life in stars; determination of the nuclear reactions that occurred in the very first stars of the universe and observational identification of the associated chemical signatures; and new insights in the origin of the heavy elements in nature through large-scale multi-institutional and coordinated observational efforts, extensive computational modeling of element synthesis and the processes that distribute elements in the Cosmos, and the experimental determination of the underlying nuclear processes with nuclear accelerators.

JINA-CEE has created significant research infrastructure that continues to be available to researchers and will have long lasting impact. This includes the establishment of the first US deep underground accelerator laboratory for nuclear astrophysics (CASPAR), the development of magnetic separator systems at the University of Notre Dame and the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams dedicated to the measurements of nuclear reactions in stars, computational codes for the analysis of experiments and the simulation of nuclear processes in the universe, and observational data analysis pipelines. Of particular importance are the interdisciplinary databases for stellar nuclear processes observations of elements in stars that continue to enable the exchange of critical data across disciplines.

A hallmark of JINA-CEE was the inclusion of early career researchers in all aspects of the center, including leading roles in scientific research, research coordination, leadership, and event organization. In total 349 students and 163 postdocs were part of JINA-CEE and received interdisciplinary and multi-institutional training that uniquely prepared them for research careers in nuclear astrophysics as well as a broad range of other careers in industry and national laboratories. Many more participated in various JINA-CEE organized schools and other training events. The resulting new generation of young scientists that live and breathe a truly interdisciplinary approach to nuclear astrophysics and are now shaping the direction of the field are an important legacy of JINA-CEE with broad and long-lasting impact. As part of its educational program, JINA-CEE developed a number of innovative school concepts that included cooperative learning approaches that turned out to be particularly well suited to overcome disciplinary or cultural barriers.

The large-scale network structure of JINA-CEE enabled the establishment of a unique suite of interdisciplinary outreach programs that included interconnected programs for students at elementary school, middle school, high school, and undergraduate levels, as well as the general public. In total JINA-CEE outreach activities reached more than 15,500 members of the public in over 35 annual in-person activities, plus more than 43,000 who've used the Isotopolis online video game. Innovative approaches included the connection of art and science for the youngest participants, or the development of TINA, a computational project framework for high school and undergraduate students that is based on the computational research network structure established in JINA-CEE and continues to be used for a range of educational and research activities.
